fields.descriptive_line: 19thC, duplicate of D 521; Hawarden C, D 520, 5 Princes Gardens, Isabella Grace, c. 1862
fields.physical_description: 5 Princes Gardens, interior: first floor, front: starred wall-paper: floor-boards: Isabella Grace, in fancy dress (Spanish style) or evening dress, standing beside Gothic-style desk (on which are ceramic figurine of male dancer in eighteenth-century dress, compotier, etc.), and fireplace, right hand on drawer knob of Indian decorated travelling cabinet (on which are two vases of flowers) on mantelpiece.
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H, case X, shelf 33H, box DUP
Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level H

fields.historical_context_note:
From departmental notes

'Clementina, Lady HawardenUntitled) Photographic Study (or) Study from Life (D.520) c.1862 5 Princes Gardens, interior: first floor, front: starred wall-paper: floor-boards: Isabella Grace, in fancy dress (Spanish style) or evening dress, standing beside Gothic-style desk (on which are ceramic figurine of male dancer in eighteenth-century dress, compotier, etc.), and fireplace, right hand on drawer knob of Indian decorated travelling cabinet (on which are two vases of flowers) on mantelpiece. Print from same negative as PH 457-1968:428 (D.521). 110 x 92 mm  PH 457-1968:473 Literature:  Microfilm: 3.19.420 The sensuous pleasure derived from the juxtapositioning of a beautiful woman in beautiful clothing--preferably draperies-­wtih a beautiful objet d'art or piece of furniture, preferably of Classical or Oriental origin, became a hallmark of the Aesthetic Movement. The combination was exploited by Albert Moore in paintings such as Pomegranates (c.1886) and by Julia Margaret Cameron in her photograph Enid (1874). Several of Lady Hawarden's photographs also use this pa1r1ng device, depicting her daughters beside Indian cabinets which she may have been given by her uncle Mountstuart Elphinstone or by her cousin John, 13th Lord Elphinstone, both of whom served as Governor of Bombay. This cabinet has been identified as a large travelling cabinet of about 1700, produced in the Deccan under European patronage, though probably not specifically for export. The materials are probably rosewood, inlaid with incised, lac-filled ivory, the decoration being derived from Indo-Persian (Mughal) sources. [Information kindly provided by Veronica Murphy, formerly Indian Section, V&A Museum.] Several of Lady Hawarden's photographs also use this pa1r1ng device, depicting her daughters beside Indian cabinets which she may have been given by her uncle Mountstuart Elphinstone or by her cousin John, 13th Lord Elphinstone, both of whom served as Governor of Bombay. This cabinet has been identified as a large travelling cabinet of about 1700, produced in the Deccan under European patronage, though probably not specifically for export. The materials are probably rosewood, inlaid with incised, lac-filled ivory, the decoration being derived from Indo-Persian (Mughal) sources. [Information kindly provided by Veronica Murphy, formerly Indian Section, V&A Museum.] This cabinet has been identified as a large travelling cabinet of about 1700, produced in the Deccan under European patronage, though probably not specifically for export. The materials are probably rosewood, inlaid with incised, lac-filled ivory, the decoration being derived from Indo-Persian (Mughal) sources. [Information kindly provided by Veronica Murphy, formerly Indian Section, V&A Museum.]'
